title: Will a bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) trade on a US exchange before 1 January 2022?
preds: After a late night shift in position without confirming if EFT in question is speculating on futures, I'm back down the low end.
My rationale is summarized in my prior forecasts.
Teach me to read the clarifications. If ETF futures and derivatives don't count, then this is obviously zero.

This is for bitcoin derivates, futures:
"The SEC is poised to allow the first U.S. Bitcoin futures exchange-traded fund to begin trading in a watershed moment for the cryptocurrency industry, according to people familiar with the matter."
"Unlike Bitcoin ETF applications that the regulator has previously rejected, the proposals by ProShares and Invesco Ltd. are based on futures contracts and were filed under mutual fund rules that SEC Chairman Gary Gensler has said provide “significant investor protections.”
"Four futures-backed Bitcoin ETFs could begin trading on U.S. exchanges this month, with deadlines for applications from VanEck and Valkyrie also approaching." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-15/bitcoin-futures-etf-said-not-to-face-sec-opposition-at-deadline?sref=PFCuwcPr&utm_campaign=socialflow-organic&utm_content=business&utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social&cmpid=socialflow-twitter-business
Too short of a deadline given regulatory timelines, should happen a bit later then that.
The party may not be quite over, but the parents have been called.
There’s been no action on this, and then indications are that the administration is cool in crypto. Lowering my estimate accordingly.

https://cryptopotato.com/sec-could-approve-a-bitcoin-futures-etf-by-october-says-bloomberg-strategist/ I wish I had updated my forecast earlier, but yeah, it's not at all likely that a bitcoin equivalent of $GLD is coming this year.

https://www.barrons.com/articles/a-bitcoin-etf-is-still-in-the-works-here-are-your-options-in-the-meantime-51618014033
Bitcoin ETFs is still in the works

SEC security Exchange Commission would consider it as a favorable option - Rise of digital transactions towards end of 2021- however concerns from fraud in cryptocurrency space  might slow this process - And potential risks of high cost 
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/19/experts-say-sec-approval-for-a-bitcoin-etf-wont-happen-any-time-soon.html
Given Bitcoin's volatility, I am skeptical that anything but futures contracts will speculate solely on Bitcoin.
Time elapsed, looks like next year is more likely

In my opinion it's worth noting that the current crowd forecast as I make this prediction is 25%. I know that this crowd are not (yet) Superforecasters and thus are likely to fall prey to various biases which would overestimate the probability. The main one being the correlation between people who think they can predict the future and people who are crypto-zealots. Thus, I would take the crowd estimate as an an unrealistic ceiling and heavily discount that signal even before doing the following  fundamental analysis: SEC has good reason to be concerned about the crimes enabled by BTC and the price manipulation of BTC that's going on currently, as well as the inherent volatility. For these reasons the chances of a BTC-only ETF are very slim. OTOH, SEC wants to have more oversight and control over the crypto markets so there's a chance they would use a BTC ETF as a wedge into it. However, the new Chair has said he's prioritizing ETFs on BTC futures already regulated on the CME (https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/new-sec-chairman-gives-his-first-speech-2149304/) which makes sense as their solution to get a wedge into the market, as then the SEC would not be responsible for investigating fraud and such in the underlying BTC market, which is impossible to do anyway. Finally, the SEC has a history of taking many years to make regulations and to approve applications on new technologies, for instance see the state of the crowdfunding regulations nearly a decade after the JOBS Act required the SEC to regulate.  From the SEC's standpoint, time is their friend; if BTC implodes or otherwise loses market dominance to the hordes of other cryptos nipping its heals, then the SEC's caution will be vindicated. On the flipside, if the approve an ETF and either of these things happens, they will look bad and so there's no actual upside of approving a BTC-only ETF. More chance that they will approve an ETF with multiple cryptos, IMHO.

"Valkyrie Investments vaulted to the front of the queue for approval from the SEC for the first U.S. Bitcoin exchange-traded fund thanks to a quirk that allows smaller issuers to file confidentially for new offerings." "The Nashville, Tennessee-based firm two months ago sought regulatory permission for a futures-based fund, likely the first company to do so before an onslaught by others following positive comments on the structure by the SEC. The request was revealed Tuesday after the Nasdaq exchange, where the Valkyrie XBTO Bitcoin Futures Fund would be listed, filed a response to the SEC" Only 4 months left til the end of the year.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-08-24/tiny-issuer-thinks-it-just-got-the-edge-in-race-for-bitcoin-etf?utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social&utm_content=business&utm_campaign=socialflow-organic&cmpid=socialflow-twitter-business
updating for time elapsed without any changes in favor.
Fidelity has filed paperwork. Gary Genslernisnheading up the SEC. He is highly knowledgeable in crypto currency. I think approval is fairly likely.

So far, Canadian financial regulators have approved four bitcoin ETFs. With the first one being in February 2021.
https://news.bitcoin.com/bitcoin-etf-approved-first-north-american-bitcoin-etf-toronto-stock-exchange/ [Feb 12, 2021] “Canada has a history of being like six months to a year ahead of the U.S.,” 
https://www.coindesk.com/bloomberg-analyst-bitcoin-etf-2021 (DATE: May 11, 2021) And with the Robinhood IPO finally being done, I guess it's about time?! Furthermore, I took some of Mr. Gensler's courses on Bitcoin and Blockchain; so he clearly does understand blockchain and crypto-currencies. Although he's not a maximalist when it comes to such technologies, he has a positive view on them.  On the other hand,
"Some of the issues and concerns that the SEC has highlighted are still out there, like the fact that most Bitcoin volume takes place outside the U.S. and therefore outside of U.S. regulatory supervision. It takes time to consider whether those issues have been addressed, says King, who plans to convert the Osprey Bitcoin Trust to an ETF whenever it’s possible."
https://money.com/when-will-sec-approve-bitcoin-etf/ [ July 12, 2021 ] Lastly, Mr. Gensler, U.S SEC chair, called recently on Congress to help rein in crypto "wild west". 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iQpuYUhMiYY [Aug 4, 2021]
There, he compared the crypto to auto industries in the beginning, where we didn't have traffic lights and other regulatory issues. 
I'm getting the sense that he's headed to first figure out/establish the regulatory landscape first, with the help of Congress. 
And definitely it's gonna take a LONG TIME for the Congress to figure out what that looks like. => So, considering all that, my money is on early 2022.
No. The SEC doesn't care they are behind Canada etc. They are walking going slowly.
Reducing further as there doesn't seem to be forward movement and time is running out. https://www.wsj.com/articles/wall-street-watchdog-keeps-bitcoin-etfs-on-ice-11626616801

More volatility on July 4 - mirroring prior weekend sell offs - is likely one of the more serious nails in the coffin of this one as of late; That type of volatility during weekend swings leaves ETF investors vulnerable in that they will either be exposed to continued losses until markets open or will be forced to hold until open - all of which could make or break individual "fortunes" (potentially) on nothing more than certain speculative whims. BTC is designed with the intent to be a digital type of currency which allows anonymous purchases through an encrypted block chain; Everyone wants to treat it like a commodity, but it can not be a commodity AND serve practical utility as a medium of exchange.  That is my two cents - er, I mean - my 0.000055 BTC on this topic.

I did not appreciate all of the work that the SEC has done on this topic already. And I did not know just how many EFT applications had already been submitted to the SEC. Also, Canada recently started approving crypto-EFTs. With these things in mind, I think it's more likely than not, but still hard to predict.

Yes; With China already rapidly moving forward with e-CNY US really have to either do major kowtows to decentralized crypto, or be forever behind. Bitcon will likely be first, as the most established crypto

so maybe i was too optimistic on this.
no special insight here so market consensus it is

The SEC once again delayed its decision saying it wants more public comments and citing worries about volatility and lack of oversight/regulation. 
Bitcoing price has perhaps been as stable as it can be hovering between 35K and barely reaching $40K in the past few weeks. There were some increases following the Miami convention, the announcement by El Salvador's decision, and news bits like Elon Musk saying Tesla will once again accept it as it gets more green energy alternatives, and Miami's mayor saying he's looking into accessing nuclear power for mining. All sound to be like desperate measures to pump the price which has failed by Bitcoin standards. Retail investors continue to see loses. Any attempt at manipulating the price to give a semblance of stability in order to get points with SEC is also failing.  Looks like there are still too many major, basic matters to take into account for approval to happen in the next 6 months

I was already wavering on this question, but now the crowd is confirming my concern. It's much more likely that a Crypto ETF be approved than a pure Bitcoin one. With the recent volatility, it's looking far less likely.

Bitcoin is struggling, even efforts by Elon Musk this week (meeting with Bitcoin Miners "Council"), and targeted headlines (like Ray Dalio saying he's bought Bitcoin and he'd rather own bitcoin than bonds) have failed to pump the price. It hovers around $40,000 then goes back down to ~$36,000). 
Bitcoin is not coming back fast enough from Musk's tweets on energy consumption, China's banning of miners, and most recently the Fed and bank regulators saying they are evaluating crypto policy. https://www.scmp.com/tech/policy/article/3134473/china-escalates-crackdown-bitcoin-mining-trading

In light of the recent volatility, it seems likely now that the SEC can and will keep delaying any ETFs this year. The SEC is being very cautious about this in ETF form, without the capacity-restriction guardrails that mutual funds have, and the SEC is closely monitoring the mutual funds and warning investors about cryptocurrency: https://www.ft.com/content/c36013a0-65a9-4f1c-901d-314577cc5266
 The expert quoted in that article does not think it's likely that anything will be approved this year.

BTC has not matured enough as a concept to invoke the confidence required for me to expect a broad acceptance amongst SEC governors in regards to any ETF related filings. While sentiment towards cryptocurrency remains positive - especially in regards to it's potential to become a standard currency in the not to distant future - so many flaws persist in the valuation of each bitcoin share; Elon musk tweets one tweet reiterating a decision made by one company (Tesla) in regards to their BTC holdings and you see bears running away with it (Down over $10K per share last 24-48-hours). This kind of volatility and subjective valuation is not a product that I believe should be sold to average Americans who do not understand that they may as well be playing black jack; Imagine a novice investor who spent his quarantine getting a BS degree in YouTube finance cashing out his Roth-IRA MF holdings so as to jump on BTC or Dogecoin - is that not cringeworthy enough of an image to see why broadening access to exposure of BTC  could end poorly, and quickly? "Put everything on BTC/Doge" sounds very similar to "Put everything on black" as even after a "winning hand" you are exposed to BTC volatility as long as you hold it, almost in the same way you are when holding your winning chips on a casino floor - and the casino quite literally banks on you prolonging that risk. That is not value investing, that is gambling, and I find it to be immoral how anyone with any fiduciary responsibility and ethical sense about them would call it anything but a gamble. All that to say, even though there may be enough popularity amongst crypto enthusiasts that a crypto-related ETF could be approved at some point in the next year which could feature BTC, I do not think it is wise at a time when markets are full of cash to put out such a risky product just so hedge fund managers can essentially "re-allocate" capital within the economy away from average uninformed and inexperienced investors who suddenly get more playing time in a game that they think will all but certainly make them "rich" almost overnight. UPDATE: Thank you @DNK89 for the link which highlights sentiments amongst analysts in regards to BTC related ETF approval; Above, I didn't even mention the environmental concerns which BTC is under scrutiny for, but that is also most certainly going to be a major factor in the SEC's decision as well https://www.barrons.com/articles/why-some-experts-think-a-bitcoin-etf-will-be-delayed-51620853749

https://www.coindesk.com/bloomberg-analyst-bitcoin-etf-2021
seems like we're getting there.
Any statements from the SEC on this?

Crowd seems super confident probably following Canada's approval and that in recent history bitcoin price has moved just one way in recent times. There is a lot of lobbying going on/ many have applied to the sec for approval. Still remain unconvinced whether this will happen. Here's Gary gensler interview  https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cnbc.com/amp/2021/05/07/sec-chairman-gary-gensler-says-more-investor-protections-are-needed-for-bitcoin-and-crypto-markets.html Will be interesting to see how Bitcoin reacts when monetary and fiscal measures tighten(which they eventually will)
Coming down from 61 to 45. There is still a lot of time for this to resolve as yes Why it might resolve as Yes
(Sec might rethink it's stance if the bitcoin prices stabilize - very slim chance or they'll succumb to some form of regulatory capture - that's a possibility
There are already substantial moves by various financial institutions including PayPal and BNY Mellon to integrate crypto into the mainstream.

SEC delays decision on approving bitcoin ETF "The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday delayed its decision on approving the VanEck Bitcoin ETF until June.
Some bitcoin watchers believe 2021 could finally be the year a bitcoin ETF is approved thanks to the Senate’s confirmation of Gary Gensler to lead the SEC.
Gensler is considered an expert on cryptocurrency and has taught courses on digital currencies and blockchain at MIT"   The SEC typically takes 45 days from when an application is filed to render a decision on whether such a security should be allowed to trade. The 45 day window for the VanEck Bitcoin ETF ends on May 3, but the SEC is extending the deadline. In the past, the SEC said it was worried about extreme price volatility and fraud in cryptocurrencies. It also noted that 75% of bitcoin trading occurs overseas on unregulated foreign exchanges that could be manipulated. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/28/sec-delays-decision-on-approving-bitcoin-etf.html
Somewhat more optimistic on this front.

I'm being risky and re-affirming. VanEck filed an application recently but I have little faith for 2021. The SEC is fearful of volatility so may want some extra time to let a price point settle just a little.

Canada’s largest digital-asset investment fund manager 3iQ Corp. is hoping to raise more than $200 million by listing its Bitcoin exchange-traded fund in Dubai https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-22/first-mideast-bitcoin-etf-aims-to-raise-more-than-200-million

Dado que Gary Gensler, profesor de Bitcoin y Blockchain en el MIT, fue nombrado presidente de la SEC por el Senado de EE.UU, tener un importante actor pro crypto dentro de la SEC da el preludio de que será posible tener un ETF de bitcoin dentro de su territorio. Además se suma el éxito que tuvo que Canadá el cual fue el primer país de América del Norte que aprobó un ETF de Bitcoin, siendo los resultados muy favorables. En dos meses ha logrado acumular un valor de más de 1.100 millones de dólares en activos bajo inversión. Una cifra que demuestra el interés y demanda potencial de los inversores por este tipo de instrumento financiero.
China's cryptocurrency launch is putting the pressure on other cryptocurrencies.

https://www.coindesk.com/sec-vaneck-bitcoin-etf-2021
VanEck filed for the ETF with Cboe BZX Exchange earlier this year, with Cboe publishing the 19b-4 at the beginning of March. Once the document is published in the Federal Register (the nation’s logbook), the general public will have 21 days to submit comments on the SEC’s portal. The SEC can extend the review period up to 240 days before it has to make a final decision. When evaluating past applications, it has always extended these decisions to their full time limit. Still not very sure what Gensler`s (recent) views are(or any change in earlier views, his committee hearings didnt give much away. In the past he has generally favored more regulation (link shared in past forecasts).

https://www.investing.com/news/cryptocurrency-news/asset-management-firm-fidelity-seeks-sec-approval-to-launch-a-bitcoin-etf-2459019
News moving in the expected direction.
No knowledge about SEC authorisation process or any of the next steps involved but given interest it seems 90% is a good estimate of regulatory inability to postpone this until 2022.

Goldman-Sachs is anticipating acceptance of BC among investors with their announcement of a digital assets group within their private wealth management team. With that, I am making a +5% upward adjustment towards being in favor of BC ETF trade on US exchange before Jan 1, 2022. https://www.barrons.com/articles/goldman-sachs-bitcoin-cryptocurrency-51617217920?siteid=yhoof2

I am increasing my odds to "in favor" due to the ETF application submitted to the SEC by Fidelity - as well as another by Vanguard - who are reputable institutions which may add more weight to the approval process if the SEC believes them capable of navigating the complexities required for managing such a fund. Still, I am hesitant to call this as certain - even though the consensus is determining otherwise - as I feel there is much uncertainty hanging over the short-term regarding Bitcoin's ability to remain stable while increasing it's overall market capitalization to a size which is more attractive to investors. Being that it's current volatility is hovering around it's average, there is still room for it to run in either direction as it has hovered over the current price range for weeks, and neither the bears nor the bulls want to take the lead; That appears to present an indicator of uncertainty among those who study these markets, so I feel it is worth noting. A quote from an article on the Fidelity ETF application submitted to the SEC: "Whether the SEC approves the plan, however, remains a key question. The regulator has not to date granted any company permission to create a bitcoin ETF, arguing that the market was not ready yet despite a growing number of applications." Source: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/24/fidelity-to-launch-bitcoin-etf-as-investment-giant-builds-its-digital-asset-business-.html

Based on these two stories I would put it at 90% at this point: 
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/24/fidelity-to-launch-bitcoin-etf-as-investment-giant-builds-its-digital-asset-business-.html
Fidelity launching a bitcoin ETF is a big deal. Like Vanguard, they are as legit as they come. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/23/bitcoin-etf-outlook-just-a-matter-of-time-market-analyst-says.html
Analyst explains that it is a matter of when, not if, because there are SEC officials now with expertise in crypto, and there are ETFs for more obscure things like natural gas and VIX futures, so Bitcoin is coming.

In Europe there are already Bitcoin ETF's (for example BTCE). With the crowd adopting Bitcoin and Blockchain related assets very fast, it is a matter of time before  this will be tradeable in the US as well.

Da es inzwischen schon Fondsgesellschaften gibt die Bitcoin Investmentfonds auflegen und aufgrund der medialen Berichterstattung über Bitcoin & Co steigt wird es bald einen Index auf Kryptowährungen geben. Daher wird es auch zeitnah die Möglichkeit für einen ETF geben und dieses Instrument aufgrund der Nachfrage der breiten Masse gelauncht werden.

This one, the Valkyrie Innovative Balance Sheet ETF, seems highly likely to be approved: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1593547/000139834421006410/fp0063501_485apos.htm  It's an ETF that is indirectly a bitcoin ETF by holding companies that have bitcoin in their balance sheets. I'm not sure whether it would trigger a yes in this question (maybe I should ask for clarification). There are many shots on goal being taken right now. This filing, for the Wisdomtree Bitcoin Trust, was just a few days ago: 
https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0001850391/000119312521077493/d122075ds1.htm People are saying that with there now being a "FOMO ETF," it's not like the SEC is rejecting these things: 
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/15/the-fear-of-missing-out-fund-shows-there-really-is-an-etf-for-everything.html

Aljazeera - "Cboe in a Monday filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission sought the green light for the VanEck Bitcoin Trust. VanEck Associates Corp. in December applied to start an ETF tracking the largest cryptocurrency. It is at least the third time since 2018 that Cboe has teamed with VanEck to seek a fund approval" Multiple sources reporting the new head of the SEC, Gary Gensler, is more open to crypto than past chairmen. Need to read into him. Also Bitcoin has had a tumble the last few weeks showing big volatility, but  so as the whole US equities market so it could be argued that its no more volatile. Adjusting forecast +5%

I'm bumping my forecast up a bit b/c Coinbase is supposed to go public in the next few months and I think that will start to normalize public crypto trading in the US. It also could go spectacularly poorly, loose a bunch of value and highlight the speculative nature of crypto currency (which is not really functioning like a currency anyway more an asset like gold)
But I think it won't go that poorly, I think having a shares in a crypto exchange trading publicly will make it more likely that the SEC approves a bitcoin ETF
https://www.coindesk.com/coinbase-s-1-trust-markets
Not happening in a post-GameStop environment.
Canadian regulators go comfortable. Expect US will as well.... absent some massive drop or spike in BTC (which is possible).

The reluctance of the SEC to authorize a Bitcoin related security ETF appears to be based on two primary factors: adequate regulatory framework to prevent currency/market manipulation, and the overall size of cryptocurrency market (currently sitting at around $50K per share). *I hurriedly posted this so as to save my initial prediction and will add my analysis which leads to the above estimation when time permits.

I don't have a great numerical base rate here. But I'm basing my thinking on the fact that several ETFs have applied and been denied by the SEC in the last few years. So the going in argument is that no, it won't get approved.  The next question is why did those other ETFs not get approved and what has changed since then that makes the applications in 2021 different. 
I found this article helpful in explaining in plain English why the SEC hasn't approved one yet "The regulatory body has refused to approve such a product on the grounds that it's uncomfortable with the risk involved in an unregulated product in an ETF wrapper. It's also worried that a bitcoin ETF would result in a rush of investors not fully understanding what they're buying" 
https://www.thestreet.com/etffocus/market-intelligence/vaneck-launch-bitcoin-etf-again#:~:text=The%20regulatory%20body%20has%20refused,product%20in%20an%20ETF%20wrapper.&text=The%20coin%2Dbased%20funds%20were,about%20the%20futures%2Dbased%20products.  That article was written before  the GameStop short squeeze and the congressional hearings that came out of that. Also before bitcoin went over 50K due partly to Elon Musk tweeting about it and buying a bunch. Also before the drama about inexperienced investors on Robinhood. So all of that makes me think that the SEC is going to be cautious about approving an ETF for bitcoin.  The underlying asset bitcoin is still an unregulated product and most consumers still don't really understand it. My gut feeling tells me that the SEC isn't in a hurry to approve it regardless of what bigger institutional investors want.
"Will government do X by [Date]?" Probably not. On the other hand, Canada has a bitcoin ETF as of 5 days ago, which has been a hit so far: https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/quote/BTCC-B.TO/

I'm somewhat out of my depth here so some bullets to structure my reasoning arround
* absence (so far) of BTC in ETF provides opportunity for listed corps to invest in BTC and offer themselves as a play on it
* banks, fund managers,... are getting swamped with regular joe's calling in to get a piece of the BTC-pie
* likely some more corps will announce over the next couple of weeks a play on BTC (apple wallet, others?) so expect the momentum to increase a little bit more
* wave of new investment is at least somewhat tied to Matt Levine's "boredom hypothesis"; once economy is fully up and running again, expect some of that money to be spent rather than sit in investment/crypto-accounts
So that's kinda of the demand side. The supply side (helping retailinvestors get exposure) is constrained by regulation for now but that easily change? I personally think the long-term play here is that BTC will be (reluctantly) integrated by banks and classic financial service providers as an asset-class they are offering exposure to...unless (geo-)polital interests dictates otherwise.
ETF-integration looks like a (logistically) easy step so i'm quite confident it is possible before next year.
the case against it rests mostly regulation dissaproval because : further craziness in the financial market (almost a given :)) and/or bitcoin getting painted as environmentally devastating and/or dominated by an evil foreign power. craziness + political willingness to fight it: 50% x 10% = 5%
+
btc reputation degrading + political willingness to fight it: 10% x 50% = 5%
=
10%
Can buy and sell options for Bitcoin? Can you leverage Bitcoin? Can governments issue Bitcoin debt? Who can issue bitcoins CDO’s?

Those in the crypto community who are optimistic that Gensler will significantly reimagine the SEC’s approach to regulating digital assets are likely to be disappointed.  In particular, we believe there is a low probability that he will revisit the SEC’s fundamental approach to treating most digital assets as securities under the Howey test.  Gensler’s resume as a regulator shows he tends to favor more regulation, not less, and he will likely feel political pressure to continue this approach at the SEC. https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.natlawreview.com/article/president-biden-s-nominee-sec-chairman-what-does-it-mean-crypto%3famp An old interview with Gary Gensler on Bitcoin
https://youtu.be/mhmds4gDK7g Base case :- They may wait for more regulation to be announced before going ahead. So less optimistic about chances of everything happening in 11 months

A couple considerations: 
There have already been several attempts at establishing Bitcoin ETFs over the years, all struck down. 
The interest by institutional investors in the space can't be understated. It is not retail investors but institutional investors that will allow this asset to flourish in the mainstream and lead to further financial instruments being created around it (i.e. an ETF)
I think a Bitcoin ETF will eventually emerge, the trouble here is timing. There are some already in the pipeline but as others have mentioned, economic tailwinds could also show the weakness of bitcoin, casting it to the fringes once again.
Quite possibly, but the volatility of BTC makes for a very unique investment tool. Knowing how and where it fits in a portfolio could be a challenge.
The news just reported the price of bitcoin just went went to 52,142.50

Current investment firms are taking a larger interest in Bitcoin as it gains in value. Blackrock added bitcoin futures trading and Tesla added $1.5 billion in Bitcoin value [1]. Additionally, Canada has just approved the first Bitcoin ETF to trade in North America, and speculators believe this could be a stepping stone to approval by the SEC [2]. Also, Cathie Wood (Ark Investment Management CEO) states that Bitcoin needs to hit a market cap of $2 Trillion dollars before the SEC will allow a Bitcoin ETF [3] and Bitcoin currently has a market cap of $600 billion. Some analysts disagree with that view and believe Bitcoin could hit a $1 Trillion market cap this year, which in turn, could convince SEC regulators to allow a Bitcoin ETF [4].  Finally, Gary Gensler was appointed to head the SEC and he has been a long-time cryptocurrency advocate [5]. Some analysts believe his advocacy could be the tipping point for a Bitcoin ETF approval [6]. Thus, I predict with a 100% probability that a bitcoin ETF will trade on a US exchange before 1 January 2022. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/17/blackrock-has-started-to-dabble-in-bitcoin-says-rick-rieder.html
[2] https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/bitcoin-etf-canada-approve-purpose-evolve-cryptocurrency-investing-fund-exchange-2021-2-1030092111
[3] https://www.coindesk.com/cathie-wood-bitcoin-etf
[4] https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/bitcoin-market-cap-could-hit-1-trillion-2021-crypto-expert-2020-12-1029908224
[5] https://www.coindesk.com/crypto-gary-gensler-sec-tea-leaves
[6] https://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-etf-2021

I see an ETF has a far more attractive investment vehicle for the layman to get into crypto without the need for a wallet, etc. An ETF for cryptos will certainly be made, its just a matter of when. I put my probability as low as 60% yes because I see a lot of tail risks in the global economy, and unlike gold I do not see people running TO bitcoin in a time of economic despair. They will look to cash out on their investment that has balloon'd.

It's a matter of the SEC approving it, NYDIG has filed for it and is expecting to hold $25B in Bitcoin for their institutional clients by the end of the year. 
Morgan Stanley (Counterpoint Global $150B fund) and JP Morgan's decision on Bitcoin will be a good sign on how fast this is going to move. Big players like Tesla going in keeps driving the price up but what happens next? There's a chance they will keep watching the price to a certain point and then cash in which would delay wide Wall St acceptance of Bitcoin as an asset class. It's a matter of time. Need to look into how Wall St and the SEC would consider the market ready enough for it. https://www.coindesk.com/nydig-microstrategy-conference
https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/bitcoin-investing-cryptocurrencies-wall-street-jpmorgan-morgan-stanley-blackrock-tesla-2021-2-1030083958
A very high probability that the IRS, SEC and major exchanges will agree on ‘regulatory standards’ for an array of cryptocurrencies.
